raw_text: 9We remove all features that occur only once in the training data. For WSJ parsing, we use the standard train (0221) /dev (22) /test (23) split and apply the NPbracketing patch by Vadas and Curran (2007)
clean_text: For WSJ parsing, we use the standard train (02-21) / dev (22) / test (23) split and apply the NP bracketing patch by Vadas and Curran (2007).

raw_text: We apply an automatic conversion process using the gold-standard NP data annotated by Vadas and Curran (2007a)
clean_text: We apply an automatic conversion process using the gold-standard NP data annotated by Vadas and Curran (2007a).

raw_text: This results in 89.3% accuracy. Recently, Vadas and Curran (2007a) annotated internal NP structure for the entire Penn Treebank, providing a large gold-standard corpus for NP bracketing
clean_text: Recently, Vadas and Curran (2007a) annotated internal NP structure for the entire Penn Treebank, providing a large gold-standard corpus for NP bracketing.

raw_text: Vadas and Curran (2007b) carry out supervised experiments using this data set of 36,584 NPs, out performing the Collins (2003) parser

The Vadas and Curran (2007a) annotation scheme inserts NML and JJP brackets to describe the correct NP structure, as shown below: (NP (NML (NN lung) (NN cancer)) (NNS deaths)) We use these brackets to determine new gold standard CCG derivations in Section 3
clean_text: The Vadas and Curran (2007a) annotation scheme inserts NML and JJP brackets to describe the correct NP structure, as shown below: (NP (NML (NN lung) (NN cancer)) (NNS deaths)).

raw_text: PropBank (Palmer et al, 2005) is used as a gold-standard to in form these decisions, similar to the way that we use the Vadas and Curran (2007a) data
clean_text: PropBank (Palmer et al, 2005) is used as a gold-standard to inform these decisions, similar to the way that we use the Vadas and Curran (2007a) data.

raw_text: This section describes the process of converting the Vadas and Curran (2007a) data to CCG derivations
clean_text: This section describes the process of converting the Vadas and Curran (2007a) data to CCG derivations.

raw_text: For example, we would insert the NML bracket shown below: (NP (DT a) (-LRB-LRB-) (NML (RB very) (JJ negative)) (-RRB-RRB-) (NN reaction)) This simple heuristic captures NP structure not explicitly annotated by Vadas and Curran (2007a)
clean_text: This simple heuristic captures NP structure not explicitly annotated by Vadas and Curran (2007a).

raw_text: Due to the annotation and work of Vadas and Curran (2007a; 2007b; 2008), we are now able to create Natural Language Processing (NLP) systems that take advantage of the internal structure of noun phrases in the Penn Treebank
clean_text: Due to the annotation and work of Vadas and Curran (2007a; 2007b; 2008), we are now able to create Natural Language Processing (NLP) systems that take advantage of the internal structure of noun phrases in the Penn Treebank.

raw_text: Vadas? internal noun phrase structure has been used in previous work on constituent parsing using Collin? s parser (Vadas and Curran, 2007c), but has yet to be analyzed for its effects on dependency parsing. Parsing is very early in the NLP pipeline
clean_text: Vadas' internal noun phrase structure has been used in previous work on constituent parsing using Collins parser (Vadas and Curran, 2007c), but has yet to be analyzed for its effects on dependency parsing.
